acne.description: Acne is a common skin condition characterized by pimples, blackheads, and whiteheads. It occurs when hair follicles become clogged with oil and dead skin cells. It's most common during puberty but can affect people of all ages.

products.name: Benzoyl Peroxide Cleanser
products.description: Helps kill bacteria that cause acne and removes excess oil from the skin.

products.name: Salicylic Acid Treatment
products.description: Helps unclog pores and reduce inflammation. Use as a spot treatment on affected areas.

products.name: Non-comedogenic Moisturizer
products.description: Hydrates skin without clogging pores. Look for oil-free formulations.

products.name: Adapalene Gel
products.description: A topical retinoid that prevents clogged pores and promotes cell turnover.

diet.name: Low Glycemic Foods
diet.description: Foods with a low glycemic index may help reduce acne flare-ups. Include whole grains, legumes, and most fruits.

diet.name: Omega-3 Fatty Acids
diet.description: Found in fish, walnuts, and flaxseeds, these may help reduce inflammation.

diet.name: Zinc-rich Foods
diet.description: Foods like oysters, pumpkin seeds, and chickpeas may help regulate oil production.

diet.name: Limit Dairy and Sugar
diet.description: Some studies suggest limiting dairy products and refined sugars may improve acne symptoms.

eksim.description: Eksim (eczema) is a condition that causes the skin to become itchy, red, dry, and cracked. It's often linked to allergens and is common in people with a family history of allergies or asthma.

products.name: Gentle Fragrance-free Cleanser
products.description: Mild soap-free cleanser that won't strip natural oils from the skin.

products.name: Thick Emollient Cream
products.description: Apply regularly to lock in moisture. Look for ingredients like ceramides or colloidal oatmeal.

products.name: Hydrocortisone Cream
products.description: For temporary relief of itching and inflammation during flare-ups.

products.name: Cotton Clothing
products.description: Wear loose, cotton clothing to reduce irritation and allow skin to breathe.

diet.name: Anti-inflammatory Foods
diet.description: Include fatty fish, turmeric, ginger, and leafy greens to help reduce inflammation.

diet.name: Probiotics
diet.description: Foods like yogurt, kefir, and fermented vegetables may help improve symptoms.

diet.name: Identify Triggers
diet.description: Common food triggers include dairy, eggs, nuts, soy, and wheat. Consider an elimination diet under medical supervision.

diet.name: Stay Hydrated
diet.description: Drink plenty of water to help maintain skin hydration from within.

herpes.description: Herpes is a viral infection caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV) that primarily affects the mouth or genital areas. It causes painful blisters or ulcers and is highly contagious through direct contact.

products.name: Antiviral Medication
products.description: Prescription medications like acyclovir, famciclovir, or valacyclovir can help manage outbreaks.

products.name: Pain Relief Cream
products.description: Lidocaine or benzocaine creams can provide temporary relief from pain and itching.

products.name: Cold Sore Patches
products.description: Hydrocolloid patches can protect the sore and promote healing.

products.name: Lysine Lip Balm
products.description: Lip balms containing lysine may help prevent and treat cold sores.

diet.name: Foods High in Lysine
diet.description: Include fish, chicken, eggs, and cheese, which may help prevent outbreaks.

diet.name: Limit Arginine
diet.description: Reduce foods high in arginine like nuts, chocolate, and certain seeds, which may trigger outbreaks.

diet.name: Immune-Boosting Foods
diet.description: Include foods rich in vitamins C and E, and zinc to support immune function.

diet.name: Avoid Triggers
diet.description: Spicy or acidic foods may worsen symptoms during an outbreak.

panu.description: Panu (tinea versicolor) is a common fungal infection that causes small, discolored patches of skin. It's caused by a type of yeast that naturally lives on the skin but can grow excessively in certain conditions.

products.name: Antifungal Shampoo
products.description: Shampoos containing selenium sulfide or ketoconazole can be applied to affected areas.

products.name: Antifungal Cream
products.description: Topical creams with clotrimazole or miconazole can treat the infection effectively.

products.name: Zinc Pyrithione Soap
products.description: Regular use can help prevent recurrence of the infection.

products.name: Exfoliating Scrub
products.description: Gentle exfoliation can help remove dead skin cells and improve treatment penetration.

diet.name: Probiotics
diet.description: Foods like yogurt and kefir can help maintain a healthy balance of microorganisms in the body.

diet.name: Limit Sugar
diet.description: Reducing sugar intake may help control yeast growth in the body.

diet.name: Garlic and Onions
diet.description: These foods have natural antifungal properties that may help fight the infection.

diet.name: Coconut Oil
diet.description: Contains caprylic acid which has antifungal properties. Can be consumed or applied topically.

rosacea.description: Rosacea is a common skin condition that causes redness, visible blood vessels, and sometimes small, red, pus-filled bumps on the face. It typically affects middle-aged women with fair skin but can affect anyone.

products.name: Gentle Fragrance-free Cleanser
products.description: Mild, soap-free cleansers that won't irritate sensitive skin.

products.name: Mineral Sunscreen
products.description: Use SPF 30+ with zinc oxide or titanium dioxide, as sun exposure can trigger flare-ups.

products.name: Anti-redness Serum
products.description: Products containing niacinamide or azelaic acid can help reduce redness.

products.name: Green-tinted Primer
products.description: Can help neutralize redness for cosmetic purposes.

diet.name: Avoid Trigger Foods
diet.description: Common triggers include spicy foods, alcohol, hot beverages, and foods containing cinnamaldehyde (cinnamon, tomatoes, citrus).

diet.name: Anti-inflammatory Foods
diet.description: Incorporate omega-3 fatty acids, turmeric, ginger, and leafy greens to help reduce inflammation.

diet.name: Prebiotics and Probiotics
diet.description: May help improve gut health, which can be linked to skin inflammation.

diet.name: Stay Cool
diet.description: Avoid hot drinks and foods that may trigger flushing. Opt for room temperature or cold options.
